perturbation.original_text: 2.7 Payment Terms. Distributor shall pay Company within thirty (30) days of Distributor's or, as the case may be, the end-user's receipt of Products.
perturbation.changed_text: 2.7 Payment Terms. Distributor shall pay Company within sixty (60) days of Distributor's or, as the case may be, the end-user's receipt of Products.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces an in-text contradiction by modifying the original payment term of 30 days to 60 days. Later in section 4.2 (A) it states the agreement may be terminated if the distributor fails to make full and prompt payment. It is unclear if prompt payment means 30 or 60 days.

perturbation.original_text: 4.2 Termination for Cause. Either party may terminate this Agreement upon 30 days Page -8- prior written notice to the other upon the occurrence of any of the following events: (A) the Distributor's failure to make full and prompt payment to the Company of all sums due and owing to it;
perturbation.changed_text: 4.2 Termination for Cause. Either party may terminate this Agreement upon 60 days Page -8- prior written notice to the other upon the occurrence of any of the following events: (A) the Distributor's failure to make full and prompt payment to the Company of all sums due and owing to it;
perturbation.explanation: This perturbation compounds the original contradiction. Section 2.7 states payments must be made within 60 days now, however this section states that the agreement may be terminated if the payment is not 'full and prompt' and the company only has to provide 60 days of notice. This means after 60 days the contract can be terminated, but that is also when payment is expected. There is no additional time to cure the payment default.

perturbation.original_text: 1.6 Distributor's Terms and Minimum Expectations. In order to maintain the exclusive rights to sell, lease, distribute and service Products in the Market, the Distributor must use all commercially reasonably efforts to purchase for sale to subdistributors the following minimum quantities of the Products from the Company: On the commencement of the Term Distributor will issue to the Company an irrevocable letter of credit ("LC") in the amount of Five Hundred Thousand Dollars ($500,000), the form of which is attached hereto as Exhibit A and incorporated herein by reference. The LC shall have a two (2) month term, and shall be renewed for five (5) consecutive bimonthly periods. A minimum of a $250,000.00 purchase order must be received by Company by the first of each month for a total (12) month period.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.6 Distributor's Terms and Minimum Expectations. In order to maintain the exclusive rights to sell, lease, distribute and service Products in the Market, the Distributor must use all commercially reasonably efforts to purchase for sale to subdistributors the following minimum quantities of the Products from the Company: On the commencement of the Term Distributor will issue to the Company an irrevocable letter of credit ("LC") in the amount of Five Hundred Thousand Dollars ($500,000), the form of which is attached hereto as Exhibit A and incorporated herein by reference. The LC shall have a two (2) month term, and shall be renewed for five (5) consecutive bimonthly periods. A minimum of a $250,000.00 purchase order must be received by Company by the first of each month for a total (6) month period.
perturbation.explanation: This perturbation changes the length of time a minimum purchase order must be received, from 12 months to 6 months. This conflicts with the minimum units outlined in the sections below (A)-(H) which are on a yearly basis. It is now unclear how the minimums for the products sold are related to the purchase orders.
